Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Environmental, Materials, and Biological Chemistry
Award.AbstractNarration: The Chemistry Department at the University of Minnesota will be running an NSF-REU program for ten undergraduate students from around the country in environmental, materials, or biological chemistry during the summers of 2009- 2011. Participants will gain a cutting edge research experience at a major research University at the forefront of chemistry in highly interdisciplinary areas. This broad research exposure will be supplemented with short classes, hands on training with high tech instruments, and visits to local government and industrial laboratories. Students will also be able to participate in the Chemists-in-the-library program, where hands-on experiments are carried out by 40-70 children at a time in local community libraries. Participants will be selected by advertising nationally and sophomores, under-represented minority groups, and 1 or 2 late bloomers who ordinarily would not get such an opportunity will be targeted. This will maximize the impact of our program and lead to the development of new scientists who pursue careers in the chemical sciences that otherwise would have picked different career pathways.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the summers 2009-2011 we had 31 NSF-REU participants performing research in the groups of 19 faculty advisers. The students were selected from nationally advertised searches in which we received 616 applications for the 3 years (319 from women, 297 from men). The selected participants came from 28 different colleges and 18 states. All participants were from external institutions. Of the 31 students, 26 came from schools with limited research opportunities. The NSF-REU fellows included 48% women, 10% underrepresented minorities, and 35% sophomores; over a longer 6-year time period from 2006–2011, the statistics are 50% women, 19% underrepresented minorities and 47% sophomores. Selection was based primarily on potential for research in chemistry, career goals, and the applicants’ school year (sophomores and juniors were preferred since these students are less likely to be already dedicated to a STEM career). A special effort was made to recruit and select underrepresented minorities and students attending community colleges. Up to $800 was made available to each student so that they could present their summer research results at a national meeting. Of our summer participants, half (50%) took advantage of this opportunity and 11 students (35%) appear as coauthors in 12 published papers in peer-reviewed journals.

The main goal of our program was to provide a rich and stimulating research experience, with emphasis on the highly interdisciplinary research areas of environmental, materials, and biological chemistry. Participants were assigned to a research adviser before the start of the summer program based upon their interests. The fact that ≈90% of the students later went on to graduate school (see below), that a third of the students ended up with a published paper in a peer reviewed journal, and that half of them presented their summer results at a national meeting (ACS and Pittcon) even though many of them (35%) were underclassmen and/or had little or no research experience is good evidence that they had a positive research experience.
